results.title: Double vision
results.creator_credit: Bede College, Durham and Christopher Mann
results.brief_description: An example of student filmmaking; set in Durham it tells the story of two fashion cameramen, during which both lose certain illusions.

results.title: Double trouble
results.creator_credit: Davidson Films and General Learning Corporation
results.brief_description: Crow and Lion, on an outer space trip, find a cell which begins to divide. The division continues until it approaches a crisis point: the two friends know the spaceship cannot contain the increasing volume of cells. A calculation has to be made to see how many days they can last. The computer read-out demonstrates a number pattern upon which a prediction can be made. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Double thread
results.creator_credit: G R Instruction and Mary Field
results.brief_description: How the daily routine is organised for the children’s own needs in a modern well-equipped nursery school in England. Every activity is designed to help the individual child’s development, and to encourage their adjustment to social and group relationships. The “double thread” refers to the inter-relations of home and kindergarten in the growing child’s life.

results.title: Double indemnity (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Joseph Sistrom, Paramount Pictures and Billy Wilder
results.brief_description: Archetypal film noir of the forties, brilliantly filmed and incisively written by Billy Wilder and Raymond Chandler, perfectly capturing the decayed Los Angeles atmosphere of a Chandler novel but using a simpler story and more substantial characters. The hero/villain was almost a new concept. Stars Fred MacMurray, Barbara Stanwyck and Edward G. Robinson. Based on a novel by James M. Cain.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joseph Sistrom, Paramount Pictures and Billy Wilder

results.title: Double concerto: a film about the pianist Roger Woodward
results.creator_credit: Angela Catterns, Abstract Productions, Endeavour Film Productions and Hugh Piper
results.brief_description: The star of “Double Concerto” is the brilliant Australian pianist Roger Woodward. His inspiration and fellow musician is the equally brilliant Polish violinist, Wanda Wilkomirska. Together they play the double concerto “Southern Cross”, a concerto written especially for them by Australia’s most internationally acclaimed composer, Barry Conyingham. The film follows Roger and Wanda in rehearsal, in concert and in rambling walks along the sea shores. They discuss their music, their politics and their personal lives.

results.title: Dots
results.brief_description: An experimental film in which both sound and visuals were created entirely by Norman McLaren drawing directly upon the film with ordinary pen and ink. The main title is in eight languages. Rereleased with multilingual titles in 1949.

results.title: Dorothy Hewett
results.brief_description: Australia’s best known female playwright, Dorothy Hewett, looks back on her childhood influences and the place of music, poetry and art in her work.
results.description: Australia’s best known female playwright, Dorothy Hewett, looks back on her childhood influences and the place of music, poetry and art in her work.

results.title: Dorothy Hewett
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers III”.
Dorothy Hewett reflects on her life as a playwright, poet, author and teacher. Hewett grew up in Western Australia and has been a writer all her life. A political, social and sexual rebel, she has created work which has often been controversial for its frankness and for the power of her female central characters. In this 1991 interview, Hewett discusses the professional and personal relationships that have enriched her life and inspired her writing. She also speaks about ageing and her struggle to overcome the loss of physical power. Research and interview: James Murdoch.
